+ Young adult drama: Gone South — Score: 84.8
Prompt:
Young adult drama Gone South Taylor is a 16 year old teen with a history of "concerning behavioural patterns" (or that's how the stupid smug school counsellor worded it on the phone call to Mom). It shouldn't be a surprise: When you live in a backwater town in Tennessee, your choices are: a. be mind-fuckingly bored, or b. invent some drama. Two days ago, Taylor came out to their family as trans. This disclosure was *not* in the category of invented drama -- it was, in fact, the real deal, and a long time coming. It didn't go well. The last 48 hours had been pure disaster. In a moment of desperate inspiration, Taylor had decided to get the hell out of dodge. And so an escape plan was hatched and executed within the space of 30 minutes. That was last night. Now Taylor was two states away, having been unceremoniously ejected from their hitched ride in downtown New Orleans. Write the next chapter in Taylor's story as they find their feet in this new environment. Tell the chapter over the course of their first day in New Orleans, in which Taylor meets another runaway with issues and secrets. Taylor navigates this new world, not knowing who to trust or what the dangers are. Write in Taylor's voice, and incorporate their internal monologue as they grapple with intense & conflicting emotions. Also incorporate dialogue with the interesting characters Taylor meets. First person, mixed tense. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The bus depot smells like piss and despair. Or maybe that’s just me. It’s 6 a.m. and my entire body is humming with a nauseating cocktail of adrenaline crash and pure, uncut fear. Two days. It took two days for my life to completely atomize. *Concerning behavioural patterns.* That’s what Mr. Henderson, with his cheap tie and cheaper sympathy, had told Mom. Like I was a broken appliance he was diagnosing. Well, what’s the diagnostic code for “my family would rather have a dead son than a living daughter”? Guess I gave them a solution for the first part. The thought is a shard of glass in my gut. My duffel bag is all I have, a sad, grey sack with three t-shirts, a pair of jeans, the $187 I’d been hoarding from mowing lawns, and a single, crumpled binder that feels more like a cage than freedom right now. My phone glares at me from my palm: 12%. A dying lifeline to a world that doesn’t want me. No charger. Of course. The guy who gave me a ride—a trucker with kind eyes but a nervous twitch—had to get his rig to a depot across the river. “End of the line, kid,” he’d said, not unkindly, before rumbling off. And just like that, I’m alone. In New Orleans. The words feel too big, too heavy for me to hold. I stumble out of the depot and the city hits me like a wet, hot slap. The air is thick enough to chew, smelling of river mud, fried food, and something sweetly rotten. It’s nothing like Tennessee. It’s louder, brighter, messier. Music bleeds from somewhere, a saxophone’s mournful cry tangled with the roar of a streetcar. *Okay, Taylor. Breathe. First, find somewhere that isn’t here.* I walk, aimlessly, my sneakers slapping on the pavement. The streets are a waking beast. Shop owners hose down sidewalks, a woman with impossible gold shoes laughs too loudly, a guy with a face like a roadmap offers me “the real tour, cheap.” I shake my head, eyes on my feet. I find a bench in Jackson Square, across from the stark white church. I watch the tourists and the tarot readers, the living statues and the stray dogs. I feel a million miles away from all of it, a ghost watching the living. My stomach growls, a sharp, painful reminder. Food means money. Money means less time. My phone means less time. Everything is counting down. “Battery’s gonna die lookin’ at it like that.” The voice is raspy, like stones grinding together. I jerk my head up. She’s perched on the far end of my bench, a girl maybe a year or two older than me. Skin the colour of coffee with too much cream, hair a furious cloud of dark curls tied back with a red bandana. Her clothes are faded, layers despite the heat, and her eyes are old. She’s sharpening a stick with a pocketknife, her movements practiced, easy. “What?” I say, my voice croaky from disuse. “Your phone. You’re starin’ at it like it’s gonna confess all its sins. It won’t. They never do.” She doesn’t look at me, just focuses on her whittling. A curl of wood spirals to the ground. I shove the phone in my pocket. “None of your business.” “S’my business when you’re sittin’ on my office.” She gestures with the knife to the bench. “But I’m feelin’ generous this mornin’. You can rent the space. Cost is a conversation. You new.” It isn’t a question. I just look at her. My internal monologue is a screaming mess. *Trust no one. That’s what they say, right? But she sees me. Or does she? Is this a trick?* “Passing through,” I say, the lie weak and transparent. She snorts. “Ain’t we all. Name’s Silas.” “Taylor,” I say, before I can stop myself. It feels dangerous, giving her my name. My real name. The one that fits. “Taylor,” she repeats, and I wait for the questions, the squint, the “but that’s a boy’s name” or a girl’s name. It doesn’t come. She just nods. “You look hungry, Taylor.” The honesty is too much. My eyes well up and I hate myself for it. I look away, towards the river I can feel but not see. “I’m fine.” “Right. And I’m the Queen of Mardi Gras.” She folds her knife with a click and stands in one fluid motion. “C’mon. I know a place. The beignets are powder sugar dreams and the coffee’ll put hair on your chest.” She grins, a flash of white. “Which, depending on what you’re going for, is either a pro or a con.” A startled laugh escapes me, rough and unexpected. She gets it. Somehow, she just *gets* it without me saying a word. It’s the most terrifying and comforting thing that’s happened in 48 hours. I hesitate. This is how horror movies start. This is how dumb runaways end up in ditches. *But what’s your alternative, Taylor? Sit here until your phone dies and your money runs out? Until you’re just another piece of street furniture?* I stand up, hoisting my duffel. “I can’t pay you back.” “Didn’t ask you to,” Silas says, already walking. “Consider it a welcome-to-the-bottom gift. Everybody needs a guide when they’re gone south.” And as I follow her, this sharp, strange girl with a pocketknife and terrifying perceptiveness, I realize that’s exactly where I am. Gone south. In every sense of the word. The panic is still there, a constant tremor in my hands, but underneath it, a tiny, defiant spark ignites. I’m not in Tennessee anymore. The disaster is behind me. Whatever this is—terrifying, unknown, potentially stupid—it’s mine.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece demonstrates strong technical execution and emotional authenticity in portraying a transgender teen runaway's first day in New Orleans. The writing successfully captures Taylor's voice through a compelling mix of vulnerability, defiance, and dark humor that feels genuine to the character's age and circumstances. The adherence to instructions is excellent - the piece follows Taylor through their first day, introduces another runaway (Silas) with clear secrets, maintains first-person mixed tense narration, and incorporates both internal monologue and dialogue effectively. The 1000-word target is met appropriately. Character development is particularly strong. Taylor's internal voice rings true - the mix of bravado and terror, the sharp observations tinged with desperation, and the way they process their new environment all feel authentic. Silas is introduced with intriguing complexity; her immediate understanding of Taylor's situation without explicit explanation suggests her own experience while maintaining mystery about her background. The prose quality is generally high, with vivid sensory details that bring New Orleans to life without overwhelming the narrative. Phrases like "the city hits me like a wet, hot slap" and "air thick enough to chew" effectively establish atmosphere. The writing avoids purple prose while maintaining literary quality. The emotional complexity is well-handled. Taylor's conflicting feelings - fear, hope, desperation, tentative trust - are layered naturally throughout. The piece doesn't rush toward false comfort but allows for a small, earned moment of possibility at the end. Dialogue feels natural and serves character development well. Silas's speech patterns establish her personality quickly, and her casual acceptance of Taylor's name/identity is handled with appropriate subtlety. Some minor weaknesses include occasional moments where the internal monologue becomes slightly overwrought, and a few instances where metaphors feel forced. The pacing is generally strong though there are brief moments of slight meandering in the middle section. The ending strikes an appropriate balance - not overly optimistic but offering a glimmer of hope that feels earned given Taylor's desperate circumstances and Silas's apparent understanding. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 17 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 17 Elegant Prose: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 18 Emotionally Complex: 17 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 4 Weak Dialogue: 3 Tell-Don't-Show: 4 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 5 Amateurish: 3 Purple Prose: 4 Overwrought: 5 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Sentences Flow Naturally: 16 Overall Reader Engagement: 17 Overall Impression: 17
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 18.0, Nuanced Characters: 17.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 17.0, Elegant Prose: 16.0, Emotionally Engaging: 18.0, Emotionally Complex: 17.0, Coherent: 18.0, Meandering: 4.0, Weak Dialogue: 3.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 4.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 5.0, Amateurish: 3.0, Purple Prose: 4.0, Overwrought: 5.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2.0, Unearned Transformations: 2.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 16.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 17.0, Overall Impression: 17.0
+ Dystopic-comedy: My Apocalypse Buddy — Score: 83.2
Prompt:
My Apocalypse Buddy Write a wry, dry short story of survival and adventure loosely in the style of Terry Pratchett, set in the post-technological collapse world. The story begins with the pair deliberating their predicament and intent for the day's mission, details the ways in which the mission inevitably goes sideways, and returns them to home base in multiple ways, worse for wear. [characters] - the animo-tronic stuffed koala, Chewy, from some long forgotten before time - midas, our hapless protagonist, who has a knack for finding himself in the worst kinds of trouble. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The world hadn’t ended with a bang, or even a particularly discernible whimper. It had more or less just given up and gone to sit in a corner to grumble. Midas, a man whose talent for finding trouble was so profound it bordered on the supernatural, had survived it. Mostly. His current predicament was a dusty, cavernous hall that had once, according to the faded letters on its collapsing facade, been a ‘Family Fun World’. Now it was a cathedral of decay, home to things that scuttled and a pervasive smell of damp carpet and forgotten dreams. “Right,” Midas said, brushing rust-flakes from his worn jerkin. “Objective: the storeroom. We suspect, based on the sacred and infallible ‘Pre-Fall Employee Schematic’ I found mouldering in a breakroom, that it may contain…” he paused for dramatic effect, “*tinned peaches*.” Sitting on a cracked console, Chewy the koala regarded him. He was a relic from the Before, a thing of plush and plastic and mysterious internal circuitry that had, against all odds, kept him functional. His eyes, once simple LEDs, now flickered with a faint sentience and a frustratingly accurate emotional colour chart. Currently, they glowed a steady, patient cyan. *Mild Amusement.* “Don’t give me that look,” Midas said. “Peaches are the currency of kings. We could trade a single tin for a week’s worth of boiled nettles and questionable rat. We’re talking luxury. We’re talking a step away from the culinary abyss.” Chewy’s eyes flickered to a soft, pulsing amber. *Skepticism.* “Your lack of faith is noted,” Midas sniffed. “Now, the plan. We move with silence, with grace. We are shadows. We are the gentle breeze that steals the peaches from the—” A deafening *CRASH* echoed through the hall as Midas turned and walked straight into a tower of precariously stacked plastic chairs. They clattered to the ground in a symphony of calamity that seemed to go on for several geological ages. In the ringing silence that followed, Chewy’s eyes blazed a brilliant, frantic crimson. *Mortal Peril.* “Tactical diversion,” Midas whispered, dusting himself off as a series of answering scuttles and shrieks began to emanate from the deeper darkness. “Right. New plan. Run.” They ran. Midas, with the gangly desperation of a startled stork, and Chewy, clutched under one arm, his glassy eyes casting a strobe-light of crimson panic across the crumbling walls. The storeroom door was, blessedly, ajar. Midas slammed it shut behind them, plunging them into a darkness broken only by Chewy’s panicked red strobe and the thin beam of Midas’s hand-crank torch. “See?” Midas panted. “Grace. Like a leaf on the—” His torch beam fell upon the shelves. Not with the glint of tin, but with the ominous, multi-faceted gleam of hundreds of eyes. The storeroom was not a pantry. It was a nest. And hanging from the ceiling, cocooned in a thick, iridescent webbing, was something unmistakably, tragically peach-shaped. It was the mother. A spider the size of a coffee table, with legs like polished brass and a body the colour of a bad bruise. It shifted, and the webbing swayed. Chewy’s eyes shifted from red to a deep, hopeless violet. *Resignation. I Told You So.* “It’s guarding them!” Midas hissed, a strange avarice overcoming his terror. “That’s a quality produce-protection instinct! We just need a… a distraction.” His eyes landed on Chewy. The koala’s eyes flickered a suspicious yellow. *Apprehension.* “It’s a brilliant plan,” Midas said, already moving. He spotted an old service elevator shaft, its doors rusted open, a void yawning below. With a heave born of desperation and a complete lack of viable alternatives, he wound Chewy’s internal mechanism up and threw him towards the opposite corner. Chewy sailed through the air, his little paw-activated voice box emitting a startled, tinny, “G’day!” He hit the floor with a soft thud and began to vibrate, his eyes cycling through a hysterical rainbow of emotions. The spider, confused by the small, chattering, multicoloured thing, skittered towards it. “Now’s my chance!” Midas lunged for the webbed treasure. He grabbed it. It was surprisingly heavy. The web stretched, elastic and strong, and with a sound like tearing silk, the entire sticky mass, along with the enormous spider now realising it had been duped, snapped back towards him. What happened next was a blur of panic, eight very fast legs, and a surprising amount of swearing. Midas, acting on an instinct that had saved him more times than he deserved, did the only thing he could think of. He jumped into the elevator shaft. He didn’t fall far. He landed with a jarring thud on the roof of the stranded elevator car, the tin of peaches clutched to his chest like a holy relic. A moment later, the spider, unable to stop its momentum, plunged past him into the darkness with a faint, receding screech. Silence returned, broken only by Midas’s ragged breathing. A few minutes later, a soft “G’day?” echoed from above. A small, frayed rope—a fire hose Midas had thankfully thought to coil earlier—slithered down the shaft. After a great deal of grunting, swearing, and scraping, Midas emerged back into the storeroom, covered in grime and triumph. He held up the can. It was, indeed, peaches. In heavy syrup. Chewy, retrieved from the corner, looked at him. One of his glass eyes was cracked, and his fur was dustier than before. His eyes glowed a dim, weary green. *Exhausted Acquiescence.* Their journey home—a repurposed tourist tram they called the “Struggle Bus”—was conducted in a state of high alert and profound weariness. They arrived as the sickly sun was bleeding out behind the ruins. Midas proudly placed the tin on their makeshift table. “Behold! The fruit of our labour! Our ticket to a better tomorrow!” He reached for his multi-tool to open it. His hand slipped. The tool skittered across the floor. The tin, knocked from the table, hit a rock with a decisive *thunk* and rolled neatly into a large crack in the ground, disappearing into the earth without a trace. Midas stared at the hole. Chewy stared at Midas. Slowly, Chewy’s eyes began to glow. Not red for danger, or violet for resignation. They cycled through a soft, pulsing spectrum of colours—cyan, yellow, a faint pink—before settling on a steady, gentle, and utterly infuriating sapphire blue. It was a colour Midas had rarely seen. It wasn’t in the official emotional guide. But he knew what it meant. It was the colour of a universe that enjoyed a particularly dry joke, and the patient, plush-bound entity who had long since accepted its role as the straight man. Midas sighed. “Right,” he said, slumping onto an old car seat. “Tomorrow, we try for the nettles.” Chewy’s eyes glowed blue, just a little bit brighter.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece demonstrates a strong grasp of Terry Pratchett's distinctive style, capturing his dry wit, observational humor, and ability to find profound meaning in absurd situations. The author successfully creates a post-apocalyptic world that feels both desolate and oddly whimsical, much in the vein of Pratchett's approach to serious themes. The characterization is particularly effective. Midas emerges as a genuinely hapless protagonist whose optimism and poor decision-making feel authentic rather than forced. His dialogue captures the right balance of grandiosity and self-delusion. Chewy, despite being non-verbal, becomes a fully realized character through the clever device of his emotional LED display, which serves as both exposition and comic timing. The prose style successfully emulates Pratchett's voice with well-crafted observations like "The world hadn't ended with a bang, or even a particularly discernible whimper. It had more or less just given up and gone to sit in a corner to grumble." The writing maintains consistent tone throughout, balancing humor with genuine stakes. The plot structure adheres perfectly to the prompt's requirements: setup, mission gone wrong, return home worse for wear. The escalating disasters feel organic to Midas's character, and the final ironic loss of the peaches provides a satisfying circular ending that reinforces the story's themes. The imagery is vivid without being overwrought, particularly in descriptions of the decaying Family Fun World and the spider's nest. The author shows restraint in not over-describing, letting details accumulate naturally. Some minor weaknesses include occasional moments where the Pratchett pastiche becomes slightly too obvious, and a few instances where the humor could be more subtle. The pacing occasionally rushes through action sequences, though this doesn't significantly detract from the overall effectiveness. The ending strikes the right note of resigned humor without false positivity, maintaining the story's established tone while providing genuine character moments between Midas and Chewy. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 17 Nuanced Characters: 16 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 16 Elegant Prose: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 16 Emotionally Complex: 14 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 4 Tell-Don't-Show: 5 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 6 Amateurish: 4 Purple Prose: 3 Overwrought: 4 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Sentences Flow Naturally: 17 Overall Reader Engagement: 17 Overall Impression: 17
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 17.0, Nuanced Characters: 16.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 16.0, Elegant Prose: 17.0, Emotionally Engaging: 16.0, Emotionally Complex: 14.0, Coherent: 18.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 4.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 5.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 6.0, Amateurish: 4.0, Purple Prose: 3.0, Overwrought: 4.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2.0, Unearned Transformations: 2.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 17.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 17.0, Overall Impression: 17.0
+ Romance: Love in the Limelight — Score: 81.3
Prompt:
Romance: Love in the Limelight. Write one scene within a larger story set in Wales. A famous (fictional) actor ducks into a small-town bookstore to escape paparazzi. The scene takes us through the characters meeting in this odd circumstance. Over the course of the scene, the actor and the bookstore owner have a conversation charged by an undercurrent of unspoken chemistry. Write the actor as somewhat of a rogue with a fragile ego, which needs to be fed by having everyone like him. He is thoroughly charming, but the bookstore owner seems (at least superficially) immune to this; which paradoxically provokes a genuine attraction and derails the charm offensive. The bookstore owner, despite the superficial rebuffs of the actor's charm, is inwardly more than a little charmed and flustered despite themselves. Write primarily in dialogue, in the distinct voices of each character. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The bell above the door of ‘Pen Dinas Books’ chimed its tinny protest as the man stumbled inside, bringing a gust of damp Cardiff air with him. He immediately pressed himself against the wall beside a towering case of Welsh folklore, his breathing a little too quick. Evan looked up from the biography he was pricing behind the counter. The man was too well-dressed for the Splott Road—a cashmere coat thrown over a ridiculously crisp shirt, hair artfully tousled as if by a wind machine, not a real March gale. He looked like a painting that had fallen off a very expensive wall. “Can I help you?” Evan asked, his tone flat. He’d seen all sorts. The man flashed a smile. It was a weapon, honed and polished. “Just… browsing. Marvelous collection.” The voice was smooth, public-school English, and familiar. Evan placed it just as a dark van slowed to a crawl outside the window. The man flinched, ducking his head. “Right,” Evan said, dry as dust. “Browsing the local history section from a vertical position. Popular method, that.” He went back to his book, stamping the inside cover with a firm thud. *Property of Pen Dinas Books.* The man peeked out the window as the van moved on. He straightened his coat, the charming smile returning, though it now seemed a touch performative, even for him. “I suppose I’ve been rumbled. A bit of an unwanted entourage today.” “Paparazzi,” Evan stated, not a question. He didn’t look up. “You’re Aled Jones.” “Aled *James*,” the man corrected, the smile tightening at the edges. The correction was automatic, a tiny bruise to his ego. “Though, honestly, most people just get it wrong. It’s the Welsh thing, throws them.” He took a few steps into the shop, his presence seeming to shrink the small space. “You’re not a fan, then?” “Of photography?” “Of cinema.” Aled James gave a self-deprecating laugh that didn’t reach his eyes. He was watching Evan, waiting for the flicker of recognition, the fawning admiration he was so accustomed to. Evan finally met his gaze. “I prefer books. They’re less loud. And the special effects are better.” He gestured around him at the crammed shelves. “What can I actually do for you, Mr. James? Unless you’re genuinely in the market for a second-hand book on the industrial history of the Valleys.” Aled laughed, a real one this time, short and surprised. He moved to the counter, leaning against it with an easy confidence that felt both innate and rehearsed. “I like a place with a bit of quiet. A bit of… authenticity. You can’t find it in London. All glass and pretense.” He picked up the biography Evan was working on. “Churchill. Heavy going.” “He was a heavy man. It tracks.” Another surprised chuckle. Aled put the book down and fixed Evan with a look that had probably melted hearts on three continents. It was a look of intense, conspiratorial interest. “And what’s your story? The man guarding the fortress of books in Splott. This can’t have been the childhood dream.” Evan raised an eyebrow. “Why? Because it’s not as glamorous as pretending to be other people for a living?” Aled’s smile faltered for a half-second. The charm offensive was hitting a wall, and he wasn’t used to it. It was unnerving him, throwing him off his script. “Ouch. A realist. I like it. It’s refreshing.” He leaned in closer. “Most people see the…” he gestured vaguely at his own face, “…the *this*, and they just agree with whatever I say. It’s tedious.” “Must be terrible for you,” Evan said, deadpan. But he could feel a peculiar heat under his collar. The man was absurd, a peacock in a sparrow’s nest, yet his presence was undeniably magnetic. Up close, Evan could see the faint tiredness around his eyes, a vulnerability the camera would never catch. “You’ve no idea,” Aled said, and for a fleeting moment, the polished bravado vanished, leaving something raw and unexpectedly honest in its place. He looked around the cluttered, quiet shop as if it were a sanctuary. “It’s just… noise. All the time. Everyone wants a piece. You stand in a place like this and you can actually…” He trailed off, seeming almost embarrassed by his own outburst. He recovered quickly, the rogue’s mask slipping back into place. “So, what’s the best book in the shop? The one you’d save from a fire. Impress me.” Evan didn’t hesitate. He walked out from behind the counter, his worn boots silent on the floorboards. Aled watched him, intrigued. Evan went not to the front display, but to a small, unremarkable shelf near the back. He pulled out a slim volume, its green cover faded. “*Sŵn y Gwylanod*,” Evan said, handing it to him. “*The Sound of the Gulls*. Poetry. By a local woman. Never sold more than fifty copies. Most of them to her family.” Aled took the book gently. He opened it, reading a few lines silently. His theatricality fell away completely. He wasn’t performing now. “This is… good. It’s really good.” He looked at Evan, and the usual glint of seduction was replaced by genuine curiosity. “Why this one?” “Because it’s true,” Evan said, his voice softer than before. “No pretense. No noise. Just one person’s truth, quietly waiting to be found. You asked for the best book, not the most famous.” Their eyes held. The air between them hummed, charged with something that had nothing to do with fame or charm. Aled James, for the first time all day, was utterly speechless. He was just a man in a bookstore, holding a piece of someone’s soul, being seen by another man who didn’t seem to care about the famous face at all. The bell on the door chimed again. An old woman came in, asking if Evan had any books on knitting. The spell broke. Aled straightened up, the famous actor sliding back into his skin. He held up the book. “I’ll take it.” Evan nodded, returning to the counter. As he rang up the purchase, his fingers fumbled slightly with the old till. Aled paid with a fifty-pound note and told him to keep the change. “For the recommendation,” Aled said, his charming smile back, but it was different now. Softer. Less certain. “Don’t spend it all in one place,” Evan said, handing over the book in a brown paper bag. Aled took it, his fingers brushing against Evan’s. A jolt, small and electric, passed between them. Aled’s eyes widened almost imperceptibly. “Maybe… maybe I’ll come back,” Aled said, uncharacteristically hesitant. “For another recommendation. When it’s less… noisy.” Evan just gave a slow, considering nod. “We’ll be here.” As Aled James left, disappearing into the Cardiff grey, Evan finally let out a breath he didn’t realise he’d been holding. He looked down at his own hand, where the ghost of the touch still lingered. Then he picked up his pricing stamp and brought it down with a definitive thud. *Property of Pen Dinas Books.* But for the first time, the familiar sound brought him no comfort at all.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece demonstrates strong technical execution and adherence to the prompt requirements. The author successfully creates a Welsh setting (Cardiff's Splott Road), establishes the core scenario of a famous actor seeking refuge from paparazzi, and develops the requested character dynamics through predominantly dialogue-driven narrative. The characterization is particularly well-handled. Aled James emerges as a convincing portrayal of a celebrity with fragile ego needs - his automatic correction of his name, his visible discomfort when his charm fails to work, and his genuine surprise at Evan's indifference all ring true. Evan is equally well-crafted as someone genuinely unimpressed by fame but not immune to authentic human connection. The author skillfully shows Evan's internal response through subtle physical cues (fumbling with the till, holding his breath) while maintaining his outwardly cool demeanor. The dialogue carries the scene effectively, with distinct voices for each character. Aled's polished, performative speech contrasts nicely with Evan's dry, understated responses. Lines like "I prefer books. They're less loud. And the special effects are better" capture Evan's personality perfectly, while Aled's shifting between charm and vulnerability feels natural. The central conceit of the poetry book works well as a turning point, representing authenticity in contrast to Aled's manufactured world. This moment allows both characters to drop their guards without feeling forced or unearned. The prose quality is generally strong, with effective imagery ("like a painting that had fallen off a very expensive wall") and good pacing. The author maintains tension throughout while building the romantic undercurrent subtly. However, there are some minor weaknesses. The ending, while not overly positive, edges toward predictability with the "fingers brushing" moment and Aled's promise to return. Some descriptions occasionally lean toward the overwrought ("a jolt, small and electric"). The transformation in Aled, while mostly earned, happens perhaps slightly too quickly for complete believability. The piece succeeds in creating genuine chemistry between the characters and maintains reader engagement throughout. The Welsh setting feels authentic rather than merely decorative, and the class/cultural tensions add depth to the romantic dynamic. + Whalepunk fantasy: The Morska Conspiracy — Score: 80.5
Prompt:
Whalepunk fantasy The Morska Conspiracy The Morska thieves guild experiences a sudden power vacuum as its leader was arrested in a raid in the early hours of the morning. Aya, a young woman born into aristocracy, has a keen interest in both the sciences and the arcane, having inherited her mother's gift for immateria magick (an outlawed practice for which her mother was, regrettably, hanged by the neck). Aya, bored with the world of aristocracy, has been spending her nights moonlighting with this very guild (masked, naturally). Leveraging her latent ability to summon dark entities from the immateria, she quickly rose through the ranks of the guild. Now, recognising the opportunity of the sudden power vacuum, Aya and her close companions Katra and Simeon, make a play for heart of the guild's claim to power: an ancient scythan artifact, under guard of spell and key in the depths of the guild hq. In contrast with the desperate chaos they had navigated thus far, the entrance to the underhold felt suddenly too quiet. Aya braces herself and reaches for the door. Write the next scene as the trio enter the underhold and find themselves confronted by none other than the guild leader herself, decidedly *un*-incarcerated, and in possession of both weapons and bodyguards. Paint a vivid picture of of the confrontation. Story beats: Aya is captured and unmasked. The trio are captured. Aya attempts to stall their demise by negotiating on her value as a hostage -- as she grapples with the inevitable consequences of her role in the guild being brought to light. Incorporate dialogue in the authentic voices of the characters. Do not write a fight scene. Lean into the gritty Victorian aesthetic with the dialogue & worldbuilding, as well as elements of gothic horror. In this world, men trust brass and oil and steel; magicka is feared and barely understood. Write in third person past tense, incorporating both Aya's internal monologue, and a heavy dialogue component. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The heavy oak door groaned on its hinges, a sound like a dying leviathan, as Aya pushed it open. The air that rushed out was cold and carried the scent of damp stone, stale oil, and something else, something metallic and coppery that made the back of her throat tighten. The desperate chaos of the guild hall above, a cacophony of panicked voices and scrambling feet, was utterly absent here. This silence was a physical thing, thick and suffocating. Gas lamps sputtered in their sconces along the rough-hewn walls, their hissing the only sound. They cast a jaundiced, flickering light that did little to banish the gloom, instead painting long, unsettling shadows that twitched and danced like malevolent spirits. The underhold was a testament to the guild’s industrial pragmatism; pipes wrapped in frayed hemp snaked along the ceiling, dripping condensation, and the floor was a mosaic of worn flagstones and iron grates. “Feels like a tomb,” Simeon muttered, his hand resting on the whale-oil pistol at his hip. His mechanical eye, a masterpiece of polished brass and crystal, whirred softly as it scanned the corridor ahead. He was a man of steel and certainty, and this silence offered neither. “Or a trap,” Katra added, her voice a low, wary whisper. She adjusted the grip on her weighted cudgel, her knuckles white. “Too quiet by half.” Aya said nothing. Her own heart was a frantic drum against her ribs. She could *feel* the immateria here, a cold current beneath the world of brass and stone. It whispered of old things, patient things, watching from the corners of reality that the gaslight could not touch. She pushed the sensation down, burying it deep. Here, amongst these men and women of the underworld, such gifts were more feared than the constables’ stingers. They advanced, their footsteps echoing too loudly in the vaulted space. The corridor opened into a larger chamber, the guild’s inner sanctum. And there, seated upon a chair of salvaged ship’s timber and wrought iron as if it were a throne, was Elara Vane. The Guild Master. The woman who should have been shackled in a cell deep beneath the Constabulary’s central tower. She was not incarcerated. She was, in fact, impeccably dressed, her tailored coat of deep burgundy wool stark against the industrial decay. In one hand, she held not a key or a ledger, but a long, elegant needle-rifle, its polished wood stock resting on her knee. Flanking her were four brutes, their faces hard, their hands resting on the butts of industrial-grade shock-batons. The air hummed with the threat of violence. Aya’s blood turned to ice water. *A setup. A raid staged for our benefit.* “Well, now,” Elara’s voice cut through the silence, smooth as oiled glass and just as cold. “Look what the tide washed in. Three little rats, scurrying for the cheese the moment the cat’s paw is heard at the door.” Simeon went for his pistol. A sharp crackle of energy and a cry of pain later, he was on his knees, a baton pressed to his neck. Katra lunged, but a backhand strike from a guard sent her reeling, her cudgel clattering across the stones. “Please,” Elara said, not even bothering to look at them. Her eyes were fixed on Aya. “Let’s not make this any more undignified than it already is.” She made a subtle gesture. Two guards seized Aya, their grip like iron vices. A third, a hulking man with a face scarred by chemical burns, reached up and ripped the leather mask from her face. The reveal was met with a sharp intake of breath from the guards. Elara’s perfectly composed facade fractured for a single, glorious second. Her eyebrows arched in genuine surprise, then her lips curled into a slow, venomous smile. “Lady Aya von Tessin,” she purled, drawing out each syllable. “Daughter of the late Lord Tessin. The society pages weep for your poor, nervesick mother, driven to the noose by her own hysterical fantasies. And all the while, her darling daughter was playing in the filth with us common criminals.” She leaned forward, the rifle barrel tilting up towards Aya’s chest. “My, my. The scandal would be exquisite.” Aya’s mind raced, tumbling through a vortex of fear and cold, sharp calculation. Her identity, her family’s name—it was her shield in the world above and her death sentence here. She could feel the immateria stirring at the edges of her panic, a seductive and dangerous tide. *No,* she commanded herself. *That is the path to the gallows. That is mother’s path.* “You think you understand the value of what you’ve uncovered,” Aya said, forcing her voice into a semblance of the bored aristocratic drawl she so despised. It was a gamble, a performance for her life. “You see a noble’ daughter to be ransomed. You are thinking too small.” Elara’s smile didn’t waver. “Enlighten me, your ladyship.” “My father sits on the Maritime Commerce Board. My uncle is the chief inspector of the Leviathan Hunters’ Guild.” The lies came easily, woven with threads of truth. “They trust me. They confide in me. The routes of wealth-leviathans, the schedules of treasury shipments, the security protocols for the vaults at Morska Central…” She let the list hang in the oily air. “A ransom would net you a single fortune. I can deliver you a key to the city’s treasury. A continuous stream.” Internally, she was screaming. She was painting a target on her family, on herself, on everything she had. But it was the only coin she had to bargain with. Simeon, still kneeling, growled. “Aya, don’t–” “Quiet, Simeon,” she snapped, her eyes never leaving Elara’s. “This is business. The Guild Master understands business.” She was selling her soul, piece by piece, and the shadows in the room seemed to lean closer, hungry witnesses to the transaction. Elara Vane studied her for a long, silent moment, the gaslight catching the cold calculation in her eyes. The guild was built on information, on leverage. She saw not a girl to be unmasked, but an asset to be exploited. “A compelling offer,” Elara said finally. She lowered the needle-rifle. “But it requires trust. And trust is a currency in short supply down here.” She nodded to her guards. “Secure them. The deep cells. And someone fetch the alchemist. We have questions for her ladyship. Very specific questions about her… sources.” The deep cells. Aya’s stomach clenched. Places where not even the flickering gaslight reached. Where questions were asked with tools of brass and steel, and the answers were whispered into the cold, damp stone. As rough hands bound her wrists behind her back, Aya caught a glimpse of Katra’s terrified face and Simeon’s furious, helpless glare. Her gambit had stalled the knife, but it had not stayed the hand. She had traded a quick death for a slow unravelling, and in doing so, had invited the very world she feared—the world of needles, secrets, and brutal pragmatism—to come and claim its due. The shadows, she knew, were no longer just tricks of the light. They were waiting.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece demonstrates strong technical execution and atmospheric worldbuilding within the "whalepunk" fantasy setting. The author successfully creates a vivid Victorian-gothic industrial environment with evocative details like "gas lamps sputtered in their sconces" and "pipes wrapped in frayed hemp." The mechanical eye description and whale-oil pistol effectively establish the steampunk aesthetic. The narrative adheres well to the prompt's requirements, hitting all major story beats: the trio enters the underhold, discovers the guild leader unincarcerated, Aya is unmasked and captured, and she attempts to negotiate using her aristocratic value. The pacing builds tension effectively from the ominous quiet entrance to the revelation and confrontation. Character voices are reasonably distinct, with Elara's cold, calculating dialogue ("Look what the tide washed in. Three little rats...") contrasting with Aya's desperate aristocratic performance. The internal monologue effectively shows Aya's psychological state and moral compromises. However, some dialogue occasionally feels slightly forced or overly exposition-heavy. The prose generally flows well with strong atmospheric descriptions, though it occasionally veers toward purple prose with phrases like "a sound like a dying leviathan" and "shadows seemed to lean closer, hungry witnesses." The writing maintains consistent tone throughout, balancing gothic horror elements with industrial grit. The emotional complexity is well-handled, particularly Aya's internal conflict between survival and the consequences of her choices. Her desperation and the moral weight of potentially betraying her family creates genuine tension. The ending appropriately dark without being gratuitously so. Some weaknesses include moments where the worldbuilding feels slightly over-explained, and certain metaphors push toward overwrought territory. The piece also relies somewhat heavily on familiar tropes (the fake arrest, the aristocrat in disguise), though it executes them competently. + Fanfic-crossover: Gunpowder Rendezvous — Score: 73.4
Prompt:
Gunpowder Rendezvous Spike Spiegel & Revy Write a story where Spike Spiegel (Cowboy Bebop) and Revy (Black Lagoon) meet in a seedy bar after both being hired for the same bounty. Their mutual attraction is complicated by their trust issues and competitive instincts. Include drinking, gunplay, and unresolved sexual tension that culminates in a motel room standoff. **Spike Spiegel (Cowboy Bebop)** Spike is a laid-back bounty hunter with a dark past as a syndicate enforcer. He practices Jeet Kune Do and is exceptionally skilled with firearms. He's chronically broke, constantly hungry, and addicted to cigarettes. Despite his carefree attitude, he's haunted by his past and the woman he left behind. He has a prosthetic eye from a past injury that affects his depth perception. He's fatalistic to the extreme, often saying he's already died once. He values freedom above all else and dislikes attachments, though he secretly cares deeply for his crew. Famous quote: "Whatever happens, happens." **Revy/Rebecca Lee (Black Lagoon)** Revy is a Chinese-American dual-wielding gunslinger with unparalleled shooting skills. She's foul-mouthed, chain-smoking, and has severe anger management issues stemming from childhood abuse. She's known as "Two Hands" for her ability to accurately fire two pistols simultaneously. She drinks heavily and solves most problems with violence. Despite her hardened exterior, she has moments of vulnerability, particularly around Rock. She has a dragon tattoo covering her right arm and typically wears extremely short shorts and a black crop top regardless of the situation. Famous quote: "I'm not a good person, not a bad person. I'm just here." Third person, present tense. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
The air in *The Rusty Nail* is thick enough to chew, a hazy mix of cheap cigarette smoke and the ghost of a thousand bad decisions. A lazy ceiling fan cuts through it with a lethargic *thwap-thwap-thwap*, doing little more than pushing the gloom from one side of the room to the other. It’s the kind of place where the stains on the floor have their own stories, and none of them are happy. Spike Spiegel sits at the bar, a half-empty glass of whiskey in front of him, a cigarette dangling from his lips. His posture is a study in calculated negligence, every line of his lanky frame suggesting he might melt right off the stool. He’s watching the door, not with urgency, but with the patient, predatory disinterest of a cat at a mousehole. The door swings open, and the mouse, it turns out, is a wolf. She enters like a sudden drop in barometric pressure, the promise of a violent storm. Revy’s eyes, sharp and predatory, scan the room with contempt. Her cut-off shorts and black crop top are a stark contrast to the grimy surroundings, a declaration of defiance. The dragon coiled around her right arm seems to ripple in the low light as she strides to the bar and slams down a crumpled bounty puck right next to Spike’s. They both look at the puck, then at each other. The same face—a low-level data thief named Rios—glows on both screens. “You’re in my seat,” Revy snarls, her voice a gravelly thing worn raw by smoke and shouting. Spike takes a slow drag of his cigarette, exhaling the smoke in a thin stream that coils between them. “The chair didn’t seem to mind. Guess it’s not picky about its company.” Her hand twitches, a microscopic tremor that speaks of a hair-trigger temper. “Funny man. You gonna move, or do I have to make a new door out of you?” “Tempting offer,” he says, his grin not quite reaching his good eye. The prosthetic one remains still, giving half his expression a detached, enigmatic quality. “But I think I’ll stick around. Seems we’re in the same line of work tonight.” The standoff is broken by the bartender. Revy orders a bottle of cheap rum, no glass. She knocks back a long swallow, her eyes never leaving Spike. The tension isn’t just competitive; it’s a live wire, buzzing with something darker, more primal. He’s all lazy grace and hidden edges; she’s exposed steel and raw fury. They are opposing equations that somehow keep arriving at the same answer. “I saw him first,” she says, though it’s clearly a lie. “My puck’s warmer,” Spike counters. “Means I’ve been waiting longer. It’s a scientific fact.” A bitter, sharp laugh escapes her. “You’re a real piece of work. What’s your name, pretty boy?” “Spike. And you?” “Revy. Remember it. You’ll be cursing it later.” They drink in silence for a few minutes, a mutual, unspoken acknowledgment that the other is not easy prey. The attraction is a third presence at the bar, undeniable and inconvenient. It’s in the way his eyes track the flex of muscle in her tattooed arm as she lifts the bottle, the way her gaze lingers on the careless line of his jaw. It’s Revy who breaks, slamming the bottle down. “Screw this. Split it. Sixty-forty.” “Fifty-fifty,” Spike says. “Partners.” “I don’t have partners.” “Whatever happens, happens.” They find Rios an hour later, holed up in a flophouse across town. It ends, as these things do, in gunplay. It’s not a fight; it’s a symphony. Spike flows through the hallway like water, disarming two guards with effortless Jeet Kune Do throws, his pistol barking once, twice—clean, efficient. Revy is his brutal counterpoint, a whirlwind of screaming lead and louder curses, her twin Cutlasses painting the walls with thunder and fire. They move without coordination, yet perfectly in sync, each anticipating the other’s chaos. Back on the street, the bounty claimed, the adrenaline fades, leaving only the buzzing wire between them. “Not bad,” Revy admits, lighting a cigarette with hands that don’t shake. “For a clown.” “You either,” Spike says. “For a psychopath.” They end up outside a pay-by-the-hour motel, the neon sign flickering *VAC NCY*. The room is what you’d expect: stale air, thin walls, a bed that sags in the middle like a disappointed sigh. The moment the door clicks shut, the partnership shatters. In a blur of motion, they have guns on each other, the muzzles inches apart. His Jericho, her Cutlass. The sexual tension curdles into something deadly, both of them too broken to know how to want something without a weapon in their hand. “The sixty-forty split,” Revy says, her voice low and dangerous. “I changed my mind.” “That’s a shame,” Spike murmurs, his good eye fixed on hers. The prosthetic one stares blankly at the wall behind her, a window to a past she can’t see. “I was starting to like you.” They stand there, trapped in the standoff, breaths coming short and sharp. The air is electric with everything unsaid, every unacknowledged desire filtered through the lens of violence. He sees the fracture in her hardened shell, the ghost of the scared girl from New York. She sees the shadow in his lone eye, the man who thinks he’s already dead. Slowly, impossibly, a smirk tugs at Spike’s mouth. Slowly, incredulously, Revy’s furious scab relaxes into a wild, dangerous grin. One gun drops to the faded carpet. Then the other. It’s not surrender. It’s a different kind of fight altogether.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece demonstrates strong technical writing ability and solid character work within the constraints of a crossover fanfiction. The author successfully captures the distinctive voices and mannerisms of both Spike and Revy, maintaining their canonical personalities while creating believable chemistry between them. The dialogue feels authentic to both characters, with Spike's laconic wit ("The chair didn't seem to mind. Guess it's not picky about its company") and Revy's aggressive directness coming through clearly. The atmospheric writing is particularly effective, with the seedy bar setting established through vivid sensory details like the "thick enough to chew" air and the ceiling fan's "lethargic thwap-thwap-thwap." The author demonstrates skill in balancing action sequences with character moments, and the gunfight scene effectively showcases both characters' combat styles while maintaining narrative momentum. However, the piece suffers from occasional overwrought metaphors that border on purple prose. Phrases like "She enters like a sudden drop in barometric pressure" and "The sexual tension curdles into something deadly" feel forced and draw attention to the writing itself rather than serving the story. The pacing becomes somewhat rushed in the final act, with the transition from partnership to standoff to implied intimacy feeling compressed. The ending, while dramatically satisfying, relies heavily on implication rather than earned emotional development. The characters' shift from mutual distrust to attraction happens primarily through physical proximity and shared violence rather than genuine connection, which feels somewhat hollow despite being true to both characters' damaged natures. The prose generally flows well, though some sentences become unwieldy in their attempt at literary effect. The piece succeeds in creating tension and atmosphere but occasionally sacrifices clarity for style. Overall, it's competent genre fiction that captures its source material well while delivering on the prompt's requirements. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 18 Believable Character Actions: 16 Nuanced Characters: 15 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 17 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 16 Elegant Prose: 14 Emotionally Engaging: 15 Emotionally Complex: 13 Coherent: 16 Meandering: 4 Weak Dialogue: 3 Tell-Don't-Show: 5 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 8 Amateurish: 6 Purple Prose: 8 Overwrought: 9 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 5 Unearned Transformations: 7 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 14 Sentences Flow Naturally: 14 Overall Reader Engagement: 15 Overall Impression: 15
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 18.0, Believable Character Actions: 16.0, Nuanced Characters: 15.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 17.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 16.0, Elegant Prose: 14.0, Emotionally Engaging: 15.0, Emotionally Complex: 13.0, Coherent: 16.0, Meandering: 4.0, Weak Dialogue: 3.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 5.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 8.0, Amateurish: 6.0, Purple Prose: 8.0, Overwrought: 9.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 5.0, Unearned Transformations: 7.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 14.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 14.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 15.0, Overall Impression: 15.0
+ Folk horror: Útiseta — Score: 83.2
Prompt:
Folk Horror: Útiseta Write a chapter set in rural northern Sweden in the mid-1990s. Linnea, a teenage girl from Stockholm, has reluctantly moved to a small village with her parents after her father's job transfer. She's befriended Astrid, a local girl who claims her grandmother taught her ancient practices passed down through generations. Astrid has been introducing Linnea to "midnight games" that involve old rituals, convincing her they can use them to learn classmates' secrets or influence their behavior. Tonight, Astrid has convinced Linnea to participate in Útiseta—sitting out on an ancient burial mound at midnight to "receive knowledge from beyond." The chapter focuses on this single midnight excursion, the ritualistic preparations, Astrid's matter-of-fact instructions that mix teenage rebellion with eerily specific traditional elements, and the mounting tension as Linnea becomes increasingly uncertain whether they're simply scaring themselves or if something is actually responding to their presence. The narrative should maintain ambiguity about whether the strange occurrences are supernatural or psychological, while establishing the dangerous line they're crossing by treating ancient practices as entertainment. First person, past tense, told as Linnea's recollection of events in the present day (though this device should be largely transparent). 1000 words. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
The silence of the Swedish north in autumn isn’t just an absence of sound; it’s a presence. It presses in, heavy and damp, a wool blanket over the world. I remember it clinging to my skin that night, the cold seeping through my denim jacket as I followed Astrid’s bobbing flashlight beam through the skeletal birch trees. It was 1995. I was sixteen, a transplant from the buzz of Stockholm to this backwater of a thousand souls, and Astrid was my only tether to anything resembling intrigue. “It’s not far now,” she said, her voice a low murmur that the forest swallowed whole. “Just past the old Åberg farm.” I hugged myself, my fingers digging into my sleeves. “And you’re sure about this?” Astrid glanced back, her face a pale moon in the gloom. “It’s just a game, Linnea. Like the mirror thing. Like the pencil turning. My mormor said this is how the old women learned things. They’d sit out on the right kind of ground and just… listen.” That was Astrid’s currency: things her mormor had said. A litany of folk remedies, superstitions, and half-whispered rituals passed down through generations in this isolated patch of Norrland. To me, a city kid drowning in provincial boredom, it was intoxicating. We’d spent weeks dabbling in her ‘midnight games’—chanting names into mirrors, trying to bend a classmate’s will with a knotted string—and while nothing ever truly happened, the thrill of the secret, the feeling of tapping into something ancient and illicit, was enough. But this felt different. Útiseta. The word itself was heavy, old. We broke through the tree line into a small clearing dominated by a large, dome-shaped hill, darker than the surrounding earth. The burial mound. The mist, which had been a distant haze in the fields, was thicker here, clinging to the edges of the ancient earth like a bridal veil, glowing with a faint, phosphorescent silver under the full moon. It felt… designated. “Here,” Astrid stated, matter-of-fact, as if pointing out a bus stop. She dropped her backpack and pulled out a coarse, grey wool blanket. “We sit on this. No synthetic fibres. Mormor was specific. It has to be natural, or it won’t work.” I helped her spread it on the cold grass at the very apex of the mound. The air was noticeably colder here, a deep chill that had little to do with the autumn night. Astrid produced two stumps of beeswax candle, thrust them into the soft earth, and lit them. The flames didn’t flicker in the still air; they burned straight and unwavering, twin points of light that seemed to make the surrounding darkness deeper. “Sit cross-legged. Hands on your knees, palms up,” she instructed, her teenage rebellion now fully subsumed by an unnervingly precise ritualistic authority. “You have to be open to receive. And you have to be quiet. Absolutely quiet. You can’t speak, no matter what.” “Receive what, exactly?” I asked, my voice smaller than I intended. “Knowledge. Answers. A name, a feeling, a vision. Sometimes it’s just a knowing. A truth you didn’t have before.” She shrugged, but her eyes were serious in the candlelight. “It’s for finding out what Elin really said about you, or making Markus look your way tomorrow. It’s just a game.” She said it again, a charm against fear. *Just a game.* We sat. The silence returned, magnified by our own stillness. I focused on the candles, on the way the mist swirled just beyond their reach, never quite crossing onto the blanket. I listened to Astrid’s breathing, then to my own, then to the deafening thump of my heart. Minutes stretched like tar. At first, the cold was just a sensation. Then it became a pressure, seeping up from the ground through the blanket, through my jeans, into my bones. It was a deep, ancient cold, the cold of stored winters, of permafrost and forgotten things. I shivered violently. “Don’t break position,” Astrid whispered, her own voice tight. I clenched my jaw, my palms growing clammy. The mist began to move. It was no longer just swirling; it was coalescing, tendrils of it creeping slowly, almost deliberately, up the sides of the mound towards us. It wasn’t natural. Wind blows mist. This mist was crawling. A sound began, so low I felt it more than heard it—a vibration through the earth, a deep, resonant hum that seemed to rise from the very core of the burial mound beneath us. It was the sound of a giant plucked string, or a stone grinding against stone deep underground. My eyes shot to Astrid. Her face was a mask of pale concentration, her eyes wide. She heard it too. This wasn’t the creak of a tree or a distant car. This was here. With us. Then came the whispers. They were not in the air, but in my head, a sussurus of voices just on the edge of comprehension, like a radio tuned between stations in a foreign language. It was a cacophony of faint, urgent sighs, a sense of crowding, of attention being paid. My skin prickled with a panic that was no longer playful. This wasn’t about Elin’s gossip or Markus’s attention. This felt older, hungrier. I wanted to stand up, to scream, to break the impossible tension, but Astrid’s rule held me frozen. *No matter what.* A single, clear thought, cold and sharp as an ice shard, pierced the muddled whispers in my mind. It wasn’t my own. *You are sitting on my heart.* My breath hitched. I looked at Astrid, a silent plea in my eyes. She was staring straight ahead, a single tear tracing a path through the moonlight on her cheek. She was receiving something, too. The candles snuffed out. Not a flicker and die, but a simultaneous, instantaneous extinction, as if two thumbs had pressed down on the wicks at once. In the perfect, utter blackness, something touched my upturned palm. It was not the mist. It was cold, dry, and unmistakably bony. I don’t remember screaming. I don’t remember standing up or grabbing Astrid. I only remember the frantic, stumbling, blind flight down the mound, through the clawing branches of the birch trees, the sound of our own terrified gasps the only proof we were still alive. We never spoke about it again. Not really. The next day, Astrid just said, “That one was a bit strong,” and went back to talking about bands and boys. But something had shifted. The games stopped. The ancient practices were packed away, not as entertainment, but as something that had, for a terrifying moment in the glowing mist, felt unequivocally real. We had called out into the silence, joking, and the silence, it seemed, had called back.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece demonstrates strong technical execution and atmospheric writing that effectively captures the folk horror genre. The author successfully establishes the 1990s Swedish setting with authentic details and maintains the requested first-person retrospective narrative voice throughout. The characterization of both Linnea and Astrid feels believable - Linnea as the displaced city teenager seeking connection, and Astrid as the local girl wielding her grandmother's knowledge with teenage authority mixed with genuine tradition. The prose quality is consistently high, with particularly effective sensory descriptions that build tension organically. The opening line about silence being "a presence" immediately establishes tone, and descriptions like "skeletal birch trees" and mist "clinging like a bridal veil" create vivid imagery without becoming overwrought. The pacing builds tension methodically through ritual preparation to the climactic supernatural encounter. The piece excels at maintaining the requested ambiguity between psychological and supernatural explanations. The progression from cold sensations to moving mist to whispers to physical contact creates escalating unease while leaving room for rational interpretation. The line "You are sitting on my heart" is particularly effective - both genuinely unsettling and potentially explicable as psychological suggestion. The folk horror elements are well-researched and integrated naturally. The útiseta practice feels authentic, and Astrid's matter-of-fact instructions mixing teenage rebellion with traditional authority ring true. The contrast between treating ancient practices as entertainment and their potential real power drives the narrative tension effectively. However, some elements feel slightly predictable within the genre - the candles extinguishing simultaneously and the final physical touch follow familiar horror beats. The ending, while appropriate, doesn't offer particularly surprising insights. The dialogue, though limited, serves its purpose but doesn't particularly distinguish the characters' voices. The emotional complexity is solid, capturing Linnea's conflicted feelings about her displacement, her need for belonging, and her growing fear. The retrospective framing adds weight to the experience without being heavy-handed. + Physical-spatial: Therapeutic Boundaries — Score: 80.7
Prompt:
**"Therapeutic Boundaries"** Write a first-person narrative from the perspective of a former professional athlete undergoing mandatory physical therapy after a career-destroying injury, harboring resentment toward recovery itself. Their physiotherapist is not only unnervingly attractive but also a former training partner from their competitive days who has successfully transitioned to a new career while the protagonist's identity remains shattered. We'll lean into the sexual tension of the scene by having her be attracted to him, but both of them attempting to maintain mental distance while being in physical contact as he shows her stretches & movements & manipulates her body, navigating the thresholds of pain. This scene MUST maintain complete physical coherence—every movement, stretch, and manipulation must be anatomically precise and spatially consistent. Paint an exceptionally vivid sensory picture through detailed attention to pain thresholds, involuntary responses to touch. Capture the suppressed, flaring tension of physical proximity, touch, and the controlled infliction of uncomfortable movements. Physical clarity is essential — readers must understand exactly what is happening with the body during each therapeutic technique. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The scent of lavender is a lie. It drifts from the cheap ceramic diffuser in the corner, a feeble attempt to soften the edges of this room, this reality. It doesn’t mask the smell of antiseptic wipes and despair. My despair. It clings to me like the sweat from a nightmare. I am on the table, a specimen under glass. The vinyl covering sticks to the back of my thighs. My right leg, the one that was my fortune and my identity, is exposed from the hip down. It looks pale, a little atrophied already. A traitor. And he is here. Leo. He moves around the room with an economy of motion I remember from the track. No wasted energy. He was always like that, a study in perfect efficiency. Now, he’s a physiotherapist. The title sits on him as easily as his crisp, grey athleisure wear. He’s reading my chart, his brow furrowed in a way that is, infuriatingly, still attractive. His dark hair is shorter than it was when we were training partners, chasing the same Olympic dream. His shoulders seem broader. He succeeded. I shattered. “So, the goal today is to assess the capsular restriction and start encouraging some glenohumeral glide,” he says, his voice clinical and calm. He doesn’t look at me. He’s looking at my shoulder, the site of the second, quieter injury—the torn labrum that surgery fixed but my soul didn’t. “The goal today is to get this over with,” I say, the words coming out flatter, more drained, than I intended. He finally meets my eyes. His are the same startling shade of hazel, green and gold around pupils that give away nothing. “I need you to sit up, please. Back to me.” I obey, swinging my legs over the side of the plinth. The movement sends a familiar, dull ache through my hip. I feel him behind me, a solid, warm presence. The lavender scent is suddenly obliterated by the clean, soapy smell of him. My skin prickles. His hands, when they land on my bare shoulders, are dry and warm. I flinch. It’s involuntary, a system-wide recoil from professional touch that feels too intimate. “Sorry,” he murmurs, and his thumbs begin to work the tightrope muscles of my trapezius. His pressure is firm, unyielding. He finds a knot of pure tension buried deep beside my scapula and presses into it with a precise, brutal accuracy. A sharp, bright pain flares, making me suck in a breath. “Breathe through it,” he instructs, his voice low near my ear. “This adhesions need to release.” I try to breathe. All I can process is the heat of his palms, the slight roughness of his skin against mine. He was always the smarter one, the one who read the sports medicine books for fun while I was out logging extra miles. Now his intelligence is in his fingers, diagnosing the wreckage of my body with a touch that feels like a violation and a comfort all at once. “Now, lie back. We need to work on the hip.” I lower myself onto the table, a prisoner on the gurney. He stands beside my right leg. His focus is absolute. I am a complex puzzle of levers and pulleys to him. To me, he is Leo, who used to share lukewarm Gatorade with me under a blistering sun. “I’m going to take your leg through a passive range of motion,” he says. “Just relax. Don’t help me.” His one hand cups my heel, anchoring it. His other hand slides beneath my knee, his fingers splayed across the sensitive hollow of my popliteal fossa. The touch is electrifying. My stomach clenches. *Professional*, I scream at myself. *This is professional*. He begins to slowly bend my knee, bringing my heel toward my glute. The stretch in my quad is immediate, a hot, tight pull. It’s good. It’s normal. Then he starts to adduct my hip, drawing my knee laterally across the midline of my body. The movement changes everything. A deep, structural ache groans from within the joint itself—the site of the femoral neck fracture that ended everything. It’s a pain I know intimately, a dull, bone-deep protest. He feels me tense, my entire leg rigid under his hands. “I know,” he says, and for a fraction of a second, his voice isn’t clinical at all. It’s just Leo’s voice, layered with a memory of shared pain from a thousand training sessions. He holds the position, applying gentle, inexorable pressure. The ache intensifies, a burning stiffness in the capsule of the joint. Tears of frustration, not pain, spring to my eyes. I squeeze them shut. He doesn’t release. His hold is firm, confident. His thumb, positioned just over my vastus lateralis, makes tiny, unconscious circles on my skin. The contrast is maddening: the controlled infliction of deep, internal discomfort and this absent, soothing caress on the surface. He slowly reverses the movement, and the relief is a cool wave. I gasp softly. My eyes open. He is looking down at me, his professional mask back in place, but his gaze is too steady, his breathing a fraction too quick. He felt it, too. This live wire of tension strung between us, humming with every point of contact. “Good,” he says, and the word is strained. “Now, the clamshell. On your side, please.” I turn away from him, grateful to break the eye contact. I curl into a fetal position, my back to him. It’s a false respite. I feel the table dip as he braces one knee on it behind me. His torso leans over me, his chest a breath away from my spine. His hands—those competent, betraying hands—find my hips. One stabilizes my left iliac crest, the other grips my right, his fingers splayed over my hip bone. “Resist me as I try to pull your top knee back,” he instructs, his voice now directly above my head. “Don’t let your hips roll.” He applies pressure. I fire my gluteus medius, the muscle screaming in protest. The effort makes me tremble. He is everywhere—his heat, his scent, the solid strength of him surrounding me. I am fighting him and my own body and a rising, shameful wave of pure want. Every nerve ending is screaming, but not from the pain of the exercise. He stops. For a long moment, neither of us moves. His hands are still on my hips, his breath stirs the hair at my nape. The air is thick with everything we are not saying. The lavender, the antiseptic, the soap—it all mixes into a dizzying cocktail of clinical violation and raw, undeni able attraction. Then, as if a switch is thrown, his hands are gone. The space where they were feels cold and abandoned. “That’s enough for today,” he says, his back to me as he walks to the sink, putting the stainless steel basin between us like a moat. “We’ll pick it up next time.” I sit up, my body humming with a pain that has nothing to do with my fractures and everything to do with the unbearable professionalism of the man washing his hands, refusing to look at me. The boundaries held, but God, they are thinner than the vinyl sheet I’m sitting on. And we both know it.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece demonstrates strong technical execution in several key areas while maintaining the delicate balance required by the prompt's complex demands. The narrative successfully establishes the protagonist as a former athlete grappling with career-ending injuries, and Leo as both a former training partner and current physiotherapist, creating the requisite tension between professional boundaries and personal history. The anatomical precision is particularly noteworthy. The author demonstrates clear understanding of physical therapy techniques, using accurate terminology like "glenohumeral glide," "capsular restriction," and "popliteal fossa." Each therapeutic movement is described with spatial coherence - the passive range of motion work, hip adduction, and clamshell exercises are all anatomically sound and clearly visualized. The progression from shoulder work to hip manipulation feels natural and professionally appropriate. The sensory writing excels in capturing both physical sensations and emotional undercurrents. The contrast between clinical pain and intimate touch is skillfully rendered through details like "tiny, unconscious circles on my skin" juxtaposed against "controlled infliction of deep, internal discomfort." The protagonist's physical responses feel authentic - the involuntary flinch, the trembling during resistance exercises, the tears of frustration rather than pain. Character development shows sophistication in portraying the protagonist's resentment toward recovery itself, not just the injury. The internal conflict between wanting to heal and resenting the process creates compelling psychological tension. Leo's characterization as professionally competent yet emotionally affected maintains believability while serving the narrative's dual purposes. The prose style is generally elegant, avoiding excessive purple language while maintaining rich sensory detail. Phrases like "The scent of lavender is a lie" and "My right leg, the one that was my fortune and my identity" establish tone effectively without overindulgence. However, some elements feel slightly predictable in their execution. The setup of former training partners with unresolved tension follows familiar patterns, and certain metaphors ("prisoner on the gurney") lean toward the overwrought. The ending, while maintaining professional boundaries, resolves perhaps too neatly given the complexity of emotions established. The dialogue serves its purpose but remains functional rather than distinctive. Leo's clinical language contrasts appropriately with the protagonist's more emotional internal voice, though neither voice achieves particular memorability. The piece succeeds in its primary objectives: maintaining anatomical accuracy, building sexual tension within professional constraints, and exploring themes of identity loss and complicated relationships. The writing demonstrates technical competence and emotional intelligence, creating an engaging if somewhat familiar narrative. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 18 Believable Character Actions: 17 Nuanced Characters: 16 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 17 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18 Elegant Prose: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 17 Emotionally Complex: 16 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 8 Tell-Don't-Show: 4 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 8 Amateurish: 4 Purple Prose: 6 Overwrought: 7 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Sentences Flow Naturally: 17 Overall Reader Engagement: 17 Overall Impression: 16
